title: 107_hr5527
content: The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" requires certain organizations to disclose their lobbying activities. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" mandates disclosure of lobbying activities for coalitions or associations identified as clients under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. They are treated as separate political organizations for tax purposes. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" requires disclosure of lobbying activities for coalitions or associations identified as clients under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. Lobbying activities are treated as exempt functions, with specific deductions disallowed and certain disclosure requirements applied instead. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" mandates that coalitions or associations identified as political organizations must notify the Secretary within 72 hours of a lobbyist's first contact. This notification must be done electronically and in writing, following the definitions of 'lobbyist' and 'lobbying contact' from the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" requires coalitions or associations to notify the Secretary of any changes in membership within 72 hours. The notice must include information such as the name, address, and contact details of each member. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" mandates coalitions or associations to inform the Secretary of any membership changes within 72 hours. The notice should include a general description of each member's business or activities and the expected contribution towards influencing legislation. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" requires coalitions or associations to notify the Secretary of any membership changes promptly. Failure to provide the required notice or include accurate information will result in a penalty equal to the specified tax rate multiplied by the amount involved. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" mandates prompt notification to the Secretary by coalitions or associations of any membership changes. Failure to comply incurs penalties based on the amount involved, which includes expected payments by the coalition or association to the filer and contributions by members towards activities. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" requires coalitions or associations to promptly notify the Secretary of any membership changes. Members are jointly and severally liable for any failure to comply with the legislation. Penalties are assessed and collected in the same manner as other tax penalties. Certain tax-exempt associations are exempt from this requirement if they fall under section 501(c)(3) and are tax-exempt under section 501(a). Certain tax-exempt associations are exempt from the disclosure requirement if they fall under section 501(c) and are tax-exempt under section 501(a). The exemption applies to associations with substantial exempt activities other than lobbying for the specific issue in question. The exemption from disclosure requirements applies to tax-exempt associations under section 501(c) and 501(a) with substantial exempt activities other than lobbying for the specific issue. Members contributing over $2,200 per year towards influencing legislation are treated as new members. The look-thru rules apply to coalitions or associations treated as political organizations, allowing them to be treated as employing or retaining others for lobbying activities. Information on these entities does not need to be disclosed in notices under section 6104. The Secretary must publicly disclose information about political organizations filing notices under section 527(k) within 5 business days. This includes a list of organizations and the information provided in the notice. The amendments made by this section apply to coalitions and associations listed on registration statements filed under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 after the enactment of this Act, and for whom any lobbying contact is made after the enactment of this Act. In the case of coalitions or associations affected by these amendments, the notice under section 527(k)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 must be filed in a timely manner. The deadline for filing the notice under section 527(k)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is 30 days after the enactment of this section.
